title: Wolfsburg 1-4 Bar√ßa Femen√≠: a thrashing to get closer to the Champions 'semis'
text:
BAR√áA FEMEN√ç
Wolfsburg 1-4 Bar√ßa Femen√≠: a thrashing to get closer to the Champions 'semis'
Published:19/03/2025 - 23:26h
Updated:19/03/2025 - 23:26h
FC Barcelona Femen√≠ took a big step towards the 'semis' of the Champions with a resounding victory in Germany against Wolfsburg (1-4)
The UEFA Women's Champions League held its other two first-leg matches of the quarter-finals this Wednesday. FC Barcelona Femen√≠ visited the always challenging Wolfsburg, but Pere Romeu's team once again imposed themselves with authority in Germany (1-4) to pave their way to another European semi-final, a stage they have reached in the last six seasons.
The azulgranas took possession from the start, but the first quarter of an hour was quite even, with few chances in the areas. In the 25th minute, a cross from Aitana ended in a goal after a failed clearance by Dijkstra, who in her effort to prevent the pass from finding a recipient in a rival ended up sending the ball into her own net. Despite the blow, the locals managed to stay in the game until halftime.
Bar√ßa sealed the match and the tie in the second half
After the break, Wolfsburg pushed forward to seek the equalizer, a factor that the Catalans took advantage of to wreak havoc in the opponent's field. In the 50th minute, Irene Paredes took advantage of a shot from Mapi Le√≥n that seemed to be going wide to extend the lead. Three minutes later, the sentence would come through Salma Paralluelo, thanks to Aitana's assist.
With the score at 0-3, the Germans made substitutions to try to stem the bleeding at the back, while Pere Romeu waited until the 70th minute to bring on Ingrid Engen and Fridolina Rolf√∂ for Salma and Esmee Brugts. The cul√©s took their foot off the gas and Wolfsburg took advantage to score thanks to a header from defender Janina Minge. Immediately after, Sydney Schertenleib came on for Alexia Putellas.
With only a couple of minutes on the field, the Swiss player scored the definitive 1-4 taking advantage of a recovery by Aitana, who passed the ball to Rolf√∂ and she to Schertenleib to complete a great collective action. Towards the end, Vicky L√≥pez and Marta Torrej√≥n would come on for Jana and Aitana, already in stoppage time. The rematch will be next Thursday at the Johan Cruyff Stadium, at 18:45.
Bar√ßa and Lyon, one step away from facing each other in the 'semis'
The Bar√ßa Femen√≠ is aiming for its fourth crown in the Women's Champions League and the third in a row. The Olympique Lyon, the tournament's top winner with 8 titles, won five consecutive editions between 2016 and 2020. This season, the final will be held at the Jos√© Alvalade Stadium in Lisbon, on May 24. The French team will almost certainly face the cul√©s in the 'semis', after the 0-2 obtained in the first leg against Bayern Munich.

author: India Today
title: How executive upskilling is fueling India's leadership pipeline
text:
India's Best Colleges 2024
How executive upskilling is fueling India‚Äôs leadership pipeline
Upskilling is a mindset that empowers individuals and organisations to grow together, shaping stronger leadership and future-ready workplaces
In today‚Äôs fast-moving world, those who grow with change are the ones who stay ahead. Leadership today isn‚Äôt defined by how long someone has been in the system or what title they hold. It‚Äôs defined by how open they are to learning, adapting and helping others move forward.
Upskilling is one of the most powerful ways professionals can unlock new opportunities. It builds confidence, sharpens thinking and deepens the sense of responsibility. It‚Äôs not just about career growth.
The best leaders are lifelong learners. They stay curious. They don‚Äôt wait for someone to push them. They actively seek new skills, perspectives and ideas. And when teams see their leaders learning, they feel inspired to grow as well. This kind of mindset builds a strong connection at work. It‚Äôs no longer just about ticking off tasks. It‚Äôs about growing together and creating a culture where people feel seen, heard and supported.
Upskilling is for everyone, not just leaders
In today‚Äôs work culture, learning and development must be for everyone. It should not be seen as a one-time activity but as part of the system. In fact, upskilling should be included in every employee‚Äôs KRA and KPI. It should be measured, supported and recognised like any other key performance area.
Organisations also need to actively encourage a culture of continuous learning. When learning is championed from the top and made accessible across levels, it becomes a shared priority, not just a personal initiative.
It also needs to be sector agnostic. Every department, not just sales or tech, needs access to learning that aligns with the company‚Äôs vision. Whether it‚Äôs HR, marketing, finance or operations, every team has a role in shaping the future. And they deserve tools that help them grow with it.
When companies make upskilling a regular practice, they send a clear message: growth is for all. Skills should evolve with changing business needs, and that evolution should happen at every level.
It reflects company ambition and builds stronger bonds
Upskilling also says a lot about the direction in which a company is headed. A business that invests in its people is serious about long-term success. In many ways, upskilling reflects the growth rate of a company. It‚Äôs a one-time investment in each employee, but the returns are long-lasting. It improves retention, strengthens trust and creates stronger alignment between individual goals and business outcomes.
Before launching any upskilling programme, it‚Äôs important to begin with conversations. Understand employees' aspirations and help them see how their growth aligns with where the company is going. These discussions bring clarity and show that the organisation values its people, not just their performance.
However, it‚Äôs important not to run generic courses just for the sake of having a programme in place. Every learning initiative should be purpose-driven and future-ready. When upskilling is planned with intention, the outcomes are more impactful for both the company and its people.
Staying relevant means staying curious
As industries continue to evolve, staying relevant means staying open to learning. New technologies and shifting market dynamics are changing not just how businesses operate, but also how roles are defined. As marketing, operations and even customer service evolve through AI, automation and analytics, the nature of jobs is transforming too.
People who invest in their development don‚Äôt just cope with change, they embrace it. They adapt faster and take on larger roles with confidence. This same thinking applies to leadership. Upskilling helps professionals move from simply managing tasks to leading with clarity and care. It strengthens decision-making, communication and problem-solving, all of which are critical in today‚Äôs unpredictable environment.
India‚Äôs growth story is closely tied to the kind of leadership we nurture. We need professionals who are driven by values, grounded in ethics and ready to guide teams through change. This kind of leadership doesn‚Äôt come from titles. It comes from a commitment to learn and lead with purpose.
When companies and employees grow together, the bond becomes stronger and more meaningful. That mutual investment lays the foundation for long-term success.
The future of work is not about standing still. It‚Äôs about moving forward with intention. Upskilling is the fuel that drives this journey. It‚Äôs not just a learning tool, it's a mindset. One that shapes careers, strengthens companies and supports India‚Äôs leadership pipeline for the future.
The author is the CEO, Jaro Education

author: Nick McKenzie
title: Building Bad: CFMEU administrator Grahame McCulloch resigns from clean-up on John Setka‚Äôs union
text:
By Nick McKenzie , Olivia Ireland and James Massola Updated September 13, 2024 ‚Äî 7.08pm first published at 7.32am Save Log in , register or subscribe to save articles for later. Save articles for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them any time.
Got it Normal text size Larger text size Very large text size Advertisement The long-time academics‚Äô union boss appointed to help clean up the Victorian CFMEU branch has suddenly resigned within weeks of his appointment after the union‚Äôs administrator received claims he used inappropriate language.
Grahame McCulloch, a former communist, was appointed in late August to take over the branch once controlled by John Setka after the federal government pushed the CFMEU into administration .
Grahame McCulloch has resigned from his position overseeing the Victorian branch of the CFMEU. Credit: Josh Robenstone
McCulloch and administrator Mark Irving, KC , were appointed following revelations of corruption, intimidation and criminal infiltration in the CFMEU in the Building Bad series published by this masthead, The Australian Financial Review and 60 Minutes .
McCulloch, the founding general secretary of the left-wing National Tertiary Education Union, was expected to lead the effort to clean up the CFMEU‚Äôs Victorian branch.
On Friday morning, a spokeswoman for the administrator confirmed McCulloch‚Äôs departure but declined to answer further questions about the reasons for his resignation.
Sources, not authorised to speak publicly, said Irving had received informal information that he believed necessitated McCulloch‚Äôs immediate departure.
Government sources familiar with the matter, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said McCulloch had used inappropriate language to women in work contexts since his appointment.
McCulloch did not respond to numerous attempts to contact him on Friday. The allegation was made informally and was not investigated.
McCulloch was a Communist Party member in the 1980s, a trait that could have enhanced his credibility with militant CFMEU members, but he has held senior Labor and superannuation roles in the years since leaving the university union in 2018.
Advertisement As Irving grapples with what he called the ‚Äúmassive‚Äù task of assuming control of the union, the old leadership regime he replaced ‚Äì which includes two now-ex senior officials contesting serious criminal charges ‚Äì has scrambled to fill the void created by the transition to administration.
Ex-CFMEU bosses Setka , Darren Greenfield and Michael Ravbar are organising fighting funds and alliances with sympathetic unions, led by the Electrical Trades Union, to create a rearguard movement aimed at destabilising Irving‚Äôs administration.
On Thursday, several large unions resolved to organise a second day of protests next week.
Union members and delegates are getting regular text messages as part of a campaign by those opposed to the administration, portraying it as an attack on hard-fought wages and conditions.
Irving, though, has stressed his intention is to keep fighting for wages and conditions while using his extensive powers to fight bribery and other forms of corruption that have become entrenched in pockets of this industry.
